Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story:
This morning, I glanced at the overflowing laundry basket and felt a familiar pang of guilt. My partner had mentioned last night that the kids were running out of clean clothes for their weekend activities, and I’d promised to handle the laundry today. As I sorted the clothes, my phone buzzed with a reminder: today was election day. The polling station was open all day, and my work schedule was light, so there was no real excuse to skip voting. Still, I could hear my partner’s voice in my head, hoping I’d finally keep my word about the laundry. 

I stood in the hallway, torn. If I left now to vote, the laundry would be pushed off again, and I’d be letting my family down—again. But if I started the laundry first, I might get caught up in chores and forget to vote, or worse, run out of time. Both roles felt urgent, both expectations pressing on me. I could feel the tension building in my chest as I weighed my responsibilities, unsure which to choose first.
